Nick Gall wrote:

> SOAP is indeed application neutral. Perhaps even more application 
> neutral than HTTP itself, since SOAP is little more than a framework for 
> an XML envelope with completely open ended XML header processing. It is 
> extremely application neutral. The problem is, interface designers take 
> the incredibly generic SOAP format and put an incredibly application 
> specific XML payload inside it. That's like stepping of a neutrality 
> cliff -- from extremely generic to extremely specific in one step.
> 
> Of course the same can happen (and does happen) with Atom entities or 
> even with representations returned by HTTP itself. But it seems to us 
> that interface designers in the REST "camp" seem to better understand 
> the importance of reusing existing representations for new applications, 
> not custom designing representations for each new application. An 
> example of this is the RESTafarian insistence that HTTP is NOT a 
> transport protocol, but rather an "application protocol", albeit a VERY 
> application neutral one. What we haven't seen yet, even from the REST 
> "camp" is much in the way of fairly generic ATOM entities to go inside 
> the ATOM "envelope". Many REST examples using ATOM step off the same cliff.

I think the problem is, you've tacked on a constraint without describing 
what it induces/constrains. With an architecture hat on I would want it 
described operationally so I can understand what benefits it brings and 
what the costs are, instead of having it defined in terms of of 
desirable outcomes or failings in other models (both serious problems 
with descriptions of SOA). I would want it called something like 
"REST+N", where "N" stands for application neutrality instead of making 
up terms like WOA.

But at a guess it sounds like you're looking for content technologies 
like RDF/OWL, or even KIF/FIPACL, which can be generically evaluated, as 
opposed to enveloping formats, which can be generically parsed. If 
that's the case, I can see how it can layer on a REST based system.

Bill
